items.title: Interplanetary living – 2017
items.text:
When we arrive on Mars, we will be very limited in what we can produce. The futuristic visions commonly found in concept art are far from the reality of initial Martian settlement. Pioneers will have few resources available to them and they will spend a long time trapped in cramped conditions before achieving a space that they can truly call home.

By combining key materials brought from earth with raw materials refined from the Martian environment, we will be able to produce 3D printable compounds for creating useful objects. The use of these printers will allow custom items to be designed on Earth for specific purposes and sent to Mars for production.

This collection is a conceptual study of items we could produce through these means. The aim is to help the astronauts feel more at home by providing traditional earth like designs, that still possess futuristic and exciting qualities.

items.title: 3D Modelling interiors for space - 2017
items.text:
Concept interior models, produced using Fusion360. I made these for research during my 'Interplanetary Living' project.

Each model is based on dimensions given by organizations such as SpaceX and Mars Society, or from real living scenarios such as rooms inhabited by staff at the Amundsen-Scott research facility near the South Pole.

items.title: Space themed vector art - 2017
items.text: Vector artwork for presentation of my 'Interplanetary Living' project.

items.title: 3D Modelling light - 2017
items.text: Concept lamp models, produced using Fusion360. I made the corner lamps into real objects as part of my 'Interplanetary Living' project.

items.title: Slim coffee table – 2016
items.text: A fresh take on coffee table design with minimum usage of wood, but with maximum strength. It holds up the weight of two people.

items.title: Tumbleweed – 2016
items.text: Simple and elegant lampshade created for the naked bulb.

items.title: Llama coat stand - 2015
items.text:
The typical coat stand is a very traditional affair. It is commonly found throughout film and TV media as a varnished, dark wood that sits in the corner of every lobby.

My aim with this piece is to challenge the traditional coat stand, which is often overlooked in a room, and turn it into a sleek, modern talking point. Having an animal head gives the design a personality, and makes it fun to hang up your hat.

items.title: Frosted bowl – 2015
items.text: Sand blasted acrylic hand-made bowl, with a flat bottom. Nice frosted outside with a glossy inside

items.title: Wooden spoons – 2014
items.text: Carved spoons for an assignment at Brighton university

items.title: Booze Octopus – 2014
items.text: A quick model of an octopus dressed up as a ghost saying “Boooozzze”.

items.title: Kitchen poster - 2014
items.text:
When moving from Sweden to UK I had big troubles converting all the measurements in the kitchen, so I created a quick and easy way to visually see conversions instead of always looking it up on the internet.

The poster comes in 3 colors, Dark green, black and red in the size A2.

items.title: Fang necklace – 2012
items.text: Ceramic fang necklaces with one fang in a holographic coating.

items.title: Alternative Time – 2011
items.text: A clock that shows time with an LED light that travels around. It will never tell you the exact time. Stress is a big problem in today’s society and I think one of the reasons is that everyone expects everything go much quicker than it actually does, so if we have a clock that shows us only full and half hours maybe people would slow down and enjoy life.

items.title: My first stool - 2010
items.text:
The first stool I made during my education at Nyckelviksskolan – Wood.

The stool is made in pine wood and painted with a thin coat of white and turquoise.

The inspiration for the stool comes from earthquakes - how the plate tectonics move to make horrible nature catastrophes for us humans.
